TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ) .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
First set of proceedings ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL )
By a summons of DATE , served on DATE , the applicant was requested to appear before the PERSON magistrate ’s court ( pretura ) on DATE on charges of breaching CARDINAL different town planning laws .

As it appears that the hearing was not held , the applicant was summoned again on DATE to appear for trial on CARDINAL DATE . Owing to a ORG strike , the trial was adjourned to DATE . On DATE evidence was heard from one of the prosecution witnesses , but the prosecution decided not to examine their second witness . Both parties asked the court to adjourn the trial to DATE . On that date the magistrate ’s court noted that the applicant had applied to ORG for his position to be regularised and had obtained planning permission for the relevant building works . The court accordingly concluded that there was no cause to continue with the criminal proceedings because there was no longer any offence .
The judgment became final on DATE .
Second set of proceedings ( no . DATE )

In the meantime , on DATE , the NORP public prosecutor ’s office had summoned the applicant to appear before the PERSON magistrate ’s court on DATE on charges of breaching CARDINAL different town planning laws . The applicant received the summons on DATE . It informed him that he was being prosecuted in his capacity as site manager . The works in question involved CARDINAL building sites that had been the subject of the first set of proceedings and CARDINAL others . The investigation had been partly conducted by the deputy public prosecutor who had been in charge of the first proceedings .

The hearing listed for DATE did not apparently take place . The PERSON magistrate ’s court adjourned it to DATE as CARDINAL of the defendants was ill . On DATE the same court adjourned the trial to DATE because the witnesses had not appeared . On that date the applicant informed the court that he had already been tried for the same offence . On DATE the PERSON magistrate ’s court concluded from the pleadings filed by the prosecution and the defence that the proceedings against the applicant could not be continued because a court decision ( which had become final on DATE ) had already been delivered in the case . The judgment of DATE became final on DATE .

“ Anyone who has been acquitted or convicted by a final judgment or order of a criminal court can not be tried again for the same offence , even if it is tried on a different basis in terms of classification , degree of seriousness or circumstances ... .

If fresh proceedings are nevertheless instituted , the court shall , at any stage of the proceedings , acquit or discharge the defendant and state the reasons for doing so in the operative part of the judgment . ”
“ The parties and counsel may at any stage of the proceedings submit written pleadings or requests to the court , which they shall file with the court registry .
The court shall rule on these duly submitted requests without delay and in any event , subject to any specific statutory provision to the contrary , within DATE . ”
